Very interesting!  I like the idea of generating useful documentation from
=
test code.  I wrote a tool & test framework with similar goals for Python
c=
alled Protest (http://xspecs.sf.net/protest.html).

One interesting effect =
I found when using Protest is that the generated
documentation was enough o=
f a different perspective on the test code that
just skim-reading it gave r=
eally fast feedback on whether the tests acted as
a clear description of th=
e tested code's behaviour.

--Nat

On 11/11/2007, Daniel Brolund <daniel.br=
olund@...> wrote:
>
>   Hi all,
> I would really appreciate some feed=
back on a small framework I'm
> writing for JUnit 4.4.
>
> I call it Bumble=
bee, and the purpose of it is to use comments and the
> structures in the t=
est-suites/cases/methods to create "human-readable"
> documentation. It is =
especially well suited for writing snippet-heavy
> documentation.
>
> In sh=
ort, Bumblebee gets events from the execution of the tests
> (suites/classe=
s/methods) and then parses the classes and methods for
> specific comments =
to include.
>
> By default it adds the de-camelcased names of the suites/ca=
ses/methods
> as headings (a la agile dox), and the contained comments beco=
mes the
> paragraphs.
>
> The comments are actually handled as Ruby-strings=
 that get executed in
> a Bumblebee execution context before being added to=
 the output. The
> execution context is
> a kind of DSL for including code-=
snippets and other things needed, and
> one of the core ideas of Bumblebee =
is that you should be able to
> extend that functionality easily.
>
> More =
detailed information about Bumblebee can be found at:
>
> http://www.agical=
.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html
>
> which is of course generated with Bum=
blebee. :-)
>
> The concept of Bumblebee is the same as for TDDoc, which me=
 and Joakim
> Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as an add-on for RMock. Unfortun=
ately,
> TDDoc became a bit of a dead-end technically, and Joakim and I tho=
ught
> it would be a good idea to start fresh. I happened to have the time =
at
> the time and I started it up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
=
> your credits to Joakim!
>
> This is an early release, and I will be very =
happy for any feedback I
> can get to improve it.
>
> Cheers
> Daniel Brolu=
nd
>
